question.title: Parallelism in Apache Camel - difference between CompletableFuture and parallelProcessing
question.body:
I have a Spring Boot Camel project that consumes messages from GCP PubSub subscription and updates 4 AWS DYnamoDB tables.

The subscription has the following parameters:

  • acknowledgement deadline (maxAckExtensionPeriod) 10 secs.
  • maxMessagesPerPoll = 5
  • concurrentConsumers = 10

The route reads the messages in protobuf format, unmarshals and updates DynamoDB tables by calling a Spring bean.

//Route
from(pubSubTopic)
  .unmarshal(protobufDataFormat)
  .bean("dynamoService", "updateDynamo") //Updates 4 DynamoDB tables.

The DynamoService is a bean that parallel updates the 4 dynamoDB tables.

@Service
public class DynamoService {
   public void updateDynamo(Object object) {
       CompletableFuture.allOf(updateTable1(object), 
                               updateTable2(object), 
                               updateTable3(object), 
                               updateTable4(object)                 
       ).join();
   }
}

During high message volume, I am seeing several messages expiring the Ack deadline and being reprocessed. The message processing latency also is higher.

I am fine tuning the consumer and looking at the way the updates are processed.

Keeping other settings same, would the throughput increase if I used .multicast().parallelProcessing()?

//Route 
    from(pubSubTopic)
      .unmarshal(protobufDataFormat)
      .multicast().parallelProcessing()
                .bean("dynamoService", "updateDynamo1")
                .bean("dynamoService", "updateDynamo2")
                .bean("dynamoService", "updateDynamo3")
                .bean("dynamoService", "updateDynamo4")
                .end()

What is the difference/impact between using CompletableFuture.allOf() vs .multicast().parallelProcessing() in the Camel Route?

I will be measuring the performance of the two designs. This question is to understand how the threading model of Camel handles the two designs.
